It was wrong for King Solomon to have married foreign women because

options.A: they would entice him to worship idols
options.B: the women of Israel were more beautiful
options.D: a king should not have too many children

explanation: The main reason it was considered wrong for King Solomon to have married foreign women was the concern that they would entice him to worship idols. In 1 Kings 11:1-4, it is stated that Solomon's many foreign wives turned his heart away from the Lord, leading him into idolatry. The principle emphasized here is the potential spiritual danger that comes from being unequally yoked with those who do not share one's commitment to God.

text: How many months were the Israelites on forced labour in Lebanon allowed to spend at home for every month at the labour camp?
explanation: According to the account in 1 Kings 5:13-14, during the construction of Solomon's temple, the forced labourers from the Israelites in Lebanon were allowed to spend one month at home for every two months of forced labour. This arrangement is mentioned in the context of Solomon's dealings with Hiram, the king of Tyre, for the supply of cedar and cypress timber for the construction of the temple.

text: Which of the following kings said, 'Behold your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt?
explanation:
The statement“Behold your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt”was made byKing Jeroboamafter he madetwo golden calvesand set them up inBethelandDan. He did this to stop the Israelites from going to Jerusalem (in the southern kingdom of Judah) to worship, thereby consolidating his rule over the northern kingdom of Israel.
1 Kings 12: 28 (RSV):
“So the king took counsel, and made two calves of gold. And he said to the people, ‘You have gone up to Jerusalem long enough. Behold your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt.’”—1 Kings 12:28 (RSV)

text: Which of these kings did not assassinate his predecessor but was assassinated by his successor?
explanation: Pekahiah was the son of Menahem and became king of Israel after his father's death. He reigned for two years in Samaria. During his reign, he did not kill his predecessor but continued the policies of his father. However, Pekahiah was assassinated by his own commander-in-chief, Pekah son of Remaliah, who then became the king of Israel. This sequence of events indicates that Pekahiah did not assassinate his predecessor but was himself assassinated by his successor.
